questions.question: What is colonization resistance?
choices: The ability of pathogens to resist antibiotics
The immune system's resistance to colonization by any microbes
The ability of the microbiome to prevent colonization by pathogenic microorganisms
The resistance of the gut to probiotic colonization
questions.answer: The ability of the microbiome to prevent colonization by pathogenic microorganisms

questions.question: Which of the following best describes immune tolerance?
choices: The immune system's ability to fight off all foreign substances
The immune system's lack of response to substances or tissues that have the potential to elicit an immune response
The tolerance of the body to high doses of antibiotics
The ability of pathogens to evade the immune system
questions.answer: The immune system's lack of response to substances or tissues that have the potential to elicit an immune response

questions.question: What are pathobionts?
choices: Harmful pathogens that always cause disease
Beneficial microbes that enhance immune function
Symbiotic microorganisms that can cause disease under certain circumstances
Antibodies that target specific pathogens
questions.answer: Symbiotic microorganisms that can cause disease under certain circumstances

questions.question: What is mucosal immunity?
choices: Immune responses that occur in the bloodstream
Immune responses that occur at mucosal surfaces of the body
The production of mucus to trap pathogens
The immunity developed after exposure to mucus-producing pathogens
questions.answer: Immune responses that occur at mucosal surfaces of the body

questions.question: What does the term 'microbiome-immune axis' refer to?
choices: The physical connection between gut microbes and immune cells
The axis of rotation of bacteria in the gut
The bidirectional communication between the microbiome and the immune system
The line separating beneficial and harmful microbes in the body
questions.answer: The bidirectional communication between the microbiome and the immune system

questions.question: When does the human microbiome begin to establish itself?
choices: In the womb
At birth
During puberty
In adulthood
questions.answer: At birth

questions.question: How does mode of delivery (vaginal vs. cesarean) affect an infant's microbiome?
choices: It has no effect on the microbiome
It influences the initial microbial colonization
It only affects the skin microbiome
It determines the child's lifelong microbiome composition
questions.answer: It influences the initial microbial colonization

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a way the microbiome influences innate immunity?
choices: Stimulates production of antimicrobial peptides
Enhances barrier function of epithelial cells
Trains neutrophils and macrophages for rapid response
Directly produces antibodies against pathogens
questions.answer: Directly produces antibodies against pathogens

questions.question: How does the microbiome affect adaptive immunity?
choices: It has no effect on adaptive immunity
It only influences B cell development
It shapes T cell differentiation and influences B cell development and antibody production
It suppresses all adaptive immune responses
questions.answer: It shapes T cell differentiation and influences B cell development and antibody production

questions.question: What is dysbiosis?
choices: The normal, healthy state of the microbiome
An imbalance in the microbiome composition
The process of acquiring new microbes
The complete absence of microbes in the gut
questions.answer: An imbalance in the microbiome composition

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a microbiome-based therapy for infectious diseases?
choices: Antibiotics
Vaccines
Fecal microbiota transplantation
Pain relievers
questions.answer: Fecal microbiota transplantation

questions.question: How might the lung microbiome be relevant to tuberculosis in Timor-Leste?
choices: It has no relevance to tuberculosis
Certain lung microbiota may have potential protective effects against TB
The lung microbiome always prevents TB infection
TB bacteria are a normal part of the lung microbiome
questions.answer: Certain lung microbiota may have potential protective effects against TB

questions.question: What is the relationship between malaria and the gut microbiome?
choices: Malaria has no interaction with the gut microbiome
The gut microbiome can influence malaria severity and transmission
Malaria parasites are part of the normal gut microbiome
The gut microbiome always prevents malaria infection
questions.answer: The gut microbiome can influence malaria severity and transmission

questions.question: How do soil-transmitted helminths interact with the gut microbiome?
choices: They have no interaction with the gut microbiome
Helminth infections can alter the composition of the gut microbiome
Helminths are a normal part of the gut microbiome
The gut microbiome always prevents helminth infections
questions.answer: Helminth infections can alter the composition of the gut microbiome

questions.question: What is the primary function of colonization resistance?
choices: To resist the colonization of any new microbes
To prevent the establishment and growth of pathogenic microbes
To resist the effects of antibiotics
To colonize the gut with beneficial bacteria
questions.answer: To prevent the establishment and growth of pathogenic microbes

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a mechanism of colonization resistance?
choices: Competition for nutrients
Competition for attachment sites
Production of antimicrobial compounds
Suppression of the host immune system
questions.answer: Suppression of the host immune system

questions.question: How does breastfeeding influence an infant's microbiome?
choices: It has no effect on the microbiome
It introduces harmful bacteria to the infant
It provides essential microbes and nutrients for immune development
It completely determines the child's lifelong microbiome composition
questions.answer: It provides essential microbes and nutrients for immune development

questions.question: What is the role of microbial exposure in early life?
choices: It should be avoided to prevent infections
It trains the immune system to distinguish between harmful and beneficial microbes
It has no significant impact on health
It only affects the skin microbiome
questions.answer: It trains the immune system to distinguish between harmful and beneficial microbes

choices: It has no impact on microbiome development
It may lead to less diverse initial microbial colonization
It always results in a healthier microbiome
It only affects the mother's microbiome, not the infant's

choices: Enhanced immune function
Increased risk of allergies or autoimmune disorders
Improved colonization resistance
Better ability to fight off all pathogens

questions.question: How might limited access to antibiotics in parts of Timor-Leste affect the population's microbiome?
choices: It would have no effect on the microbiome
It might result in a less diverse microbiome
It could lead to a more diverse and resilient microbiome
It would cause immediate health problems

Using culturally appropriate, simple messages in local languages
Only through formal school curricula

choices: It has no relevance to malnutrition
